15 kiromita i te tuawhenua mai i Waitangi, kei te Huarahi Porotū tata mai ki te ara matua 10 te marae o Oromāhoe. Nō Ngāti Kawa, Ngāti Rāhiri hapū o Ngāpuhi tēnei marae. Ko Pouerua te maunga, ko Ōwhareiti te roto, ko Waiaruhe te awa. 
Ko Ngāti Kawa te wharenui, ko Kuiapō te wharekai. Kei koni tata mai i te marae o Oromāhoe ko te Whare Karakia o Matiu.

description.en:
Parawhenua marae is located on the corner of State Highway 1 and Waimate/Te Ahuahu Road. It stands close to Lake Omapere, and below the maunga of Te Ahu Ahu.
The principal hapū of Parawhenua marae are Te Uri Taniwha, Ngāti Hineira, Ngāti Korohue and Te Whanauwhero of the Ngāpuhi confederation.
description.mi:
Kei te pekanga o te ara matua 1 me te Huarahi Waimate/Te Ahuahu te marae o Parawhenua. E tū tata atu ana ki te roto o Ōmāpere i raro iho i ngā rekereke o te maunga o Te Ahuahu.

Ko ngā hapū matua o te marae ko Ngāti Hineira, Ngāti Korohue, Te Uri Taniwha me Te Whānauwhero hapū o Ngāpuhi.

description.en:
Waimahana marae can be found in the Far North behind the very isolated Waimahana Bay. It affiliates to Ngāti Kahu ki Whangaroa and the Ngāpuhi confederation. 
The wharenui is named Te Puhi o Te Waka.
Turn left at 227 Taupo Bay Road, drive for 8km (keep left) to Waimahana Bay. Drive along beachfront track to marae (300 m up creek)

Parakao marae (also known as Te Aroha) is located in Parakao. It belongs to the hapū Ngāti Te Rino of the Ngapuhi iwi. Parakao marae also shares genealogical links with futher hapū Ngati Horahia, Ngati Moe, Ngati Toki and Te Parawhau.
The wharenui is named Te Aroha.
description.mi:
Kei Parakao te marae o Parakao (Te Aroha). Nō te hapū Ngāti Te Rino o Ngāpuhi tēnei marae. He whanaungatanga ano tenei marae ki nga hapū o Ngāti Horahia, Ngāti Moe, Ngāti Toki me Te Parawhau
Ko Te Aroha te wharenui.

description.en:
Mangaiti marae is on the western side of Kaeo on Omaunu Road. Its wharenui is called Tau Te Rangimarie (22/03/1928) and has links to the hapu of Ngāti Pakahi and Ngāti Uru. 
 
The marae is in the tribal area of Ngāti Kahu ki Whangaroa.
description.mi: Kei te taha ki te uru o Kaeo te marae o Mangaiti, kei te Huarahi Ōmaunu. Ko Tau Te Rangimārie te wharenui, ko ngā hapū ko Ngāti Pākahi me Ngāti Uru. Kei te rohe pōtae o te iwi Ngāti Kahu ki Whangaroa.

description.en:
Kenana marae is located on the eastern side of Mangonui on Kenana Road, off Kohumaru Road.
The wharenui is called Te Ranginui, and is associated to the hapu of Matarahurahu, of Ngāti Kahu.
description.mi: Kei te taha marangai o Mangonui kei te Huarahi o Kēnana, whiti mai i te Huarahi o Kohumaru te marae o Kēnana. Ko Te Ranginui te wharenui, ko te Matarahurahu te hapū o Ngāti Kuri iwi.

description.en:
Te Pātūnga marae is in close proximity to the Northland township of Kaeo on State Highway 10. It is connected to Ngāti Uru and Te Aeto hapu of Ngāti Kahu ki Whangaroa.
Te Watea is the name of their wharenui.
description.mi:
Te Pātūnga marae is in close proximity to the Northland township of Kaeo on State Highway 10. It is connected to Ngāti Uru and Te Aeto hapu of Ngāti Kahu ki Whangaroa.
Te Watea is the name of their wharenui.

description.en:
Takahiwai marae is situated in Ruakaka, Northland. This marae belongs to the Patuharekeke hapu of the Ngāti Whatua confederation; Ngāpuhi and Ngāti Wai.
The wharenui is named Rangiora and there is a kohanga reo onsite. The marae connects to the maunga called Manaia and to the major harbor named Whangarei te Rerenga Paraoa.
Link to further information on Te Wehi NuiLink to further information on Te Wehi Nui
description.mi: Kei Ruakākā runga mai i Whangarei te marae o Takahiwai. Nō Te Patuharakeke hapū o Ngāpuhi tēnei marae. Ko Rangiora te wharenui, ā, he kohanga reo kei kona. Ko Manaia te maunga ko Whangarei Te Terenga Parāoa te moana.

description.en:
Matangirau marae is on the eastern side of the Whangaroa Harbour near Waitapu Bay. Its wharenui is named Karangahape.
This marae is associated with Ngāti Kahu ki Whangaroa and Ngāpuhi. Its ancestral landmarks are the maunga named Ohau Tieke and Te Towai River.
description.mi:
Kei te taha rāwhiti o Whangaroa tata atu ki te whanga Waitapu te marae o Matangirau.
Ko Te Karangahape te wharenui. Nō Ngāti Kahu ki Whangaroa me Ngāpuhi tēnei marae. Ko Ōhau Tieke te maunga, ko Te Tōwai te awa.

description.en:
Te Wainui marae is located just west of Whatatutu, 50 km inland from Gisborne. It belongs to the hapū Ngariki of Te Aitanga ā Māhaki.
The whare is named Te Whare o Hera. The marae ancestrally connects to the waka Horouta, and is further defined by the awa Māngatu and the maunga Maungahaumi.
description.mi:
Kei te uru o Whatatutu te marae o Te Wainui, 50 kiromita whakatuawhenua atu i Tūranganui a Kiwa. Ko te hapū matua o tēnei marae ko Ngāriki o Te Aitanga-a-Māhaki.
Ko te ingoa o te whare ko Te Whare o Hera. Ko ōna herenga kōrero, ko Horouta te waka, ko Mangatū te awa, ko Maungahaumi te maunga.

wikipedia.en: The Cavalli Islands are a small group of islands near Whangaroa on Northland's East Coast in northern New Zealand. They lie 3 kilometres (1.9 mi) to the east of Matauri Bay on the mainland.

description.en:
Mangamuka marae is just off State Highway 1 south of the Mangamuka range. It belongs to the Ngāpuhi confederation and the wharenui is called Ngāpuhi (Puhi Kai Ariki, Puhi Moana Ariki, Puhi Taniwharau).  
Mangamuka marae connects to the nearby maunga named Maungataniwha and to the Hokianga Harbour.
description.mi: Kei te ara matua 1 kei runga ake i ngā pae maunga o Mangamuka te marae o Mangamuka. Nō te iwi o Ngāpuhi tēnei marae. Ko Ngāpuhi (Puhi Kai Ariki, Puhi Moana Ariki, Puhi Taniwharau) te wharenui, ko Maunga Taniwha te maunga ko Hokianga te moana.

description.en:
Ngāi Tupoto marae is located on the northern side of the Hokianga Harbour at Motukaraka Point in the Far North.
The primary hapū for the marae are Ngāi Tupoto and Ngāti Here of Te Rarawa. The wharenui is named Ngāhuia.
description.mi:
Ngāi Tupoto marae is located on the northern side of the Hokianga Harbour at Motukaraka Point in the Far North.
The primary hapū for the marae are Ngāi Tupoto and Ngāti Here of Te Rarawa. The wharenui is named Ngāhuia.

description.en:
Ngāti Manawa marae, also known as Te Waiariki, is located on West Coast Road in the North Hokianga settlement of Panguru. Its principal hapū are Ngāti Manawa, Waiāriki and Te Kaitutae of Te Rarawa.
The wharenui is also called Ngāti Manawa and the wharekai is Kia Mataara. The marae connects ancestrally to the maunga Panguru.
description.mi:
Ngāti Manawa marae, also known as Te Waiariki, is located on West Coast Road in the North Hokianga settlement of Panguru. Its principal hapū are Ngāti Manawa, Waiāriki and Te Kaitutae of Te Rarawa.
The wharenui is also called Ngāti Manawa and the wharekai is Kia Mataara. The marae connects ancestrally to the maunga Panguru.

description.en:
Pateoro (Te Karae) marae, is located on Te Karae Road, Kohukohu, in the northern reaches of Hokianga Harbour. 
The wharenui is Pōwhiri and the wharekai is Ngā Reo o Ngā Whaea. Pateoro marae affiliates to Te Ihutai hapū within the iwi of Te Rarawa and connects ancestrally to Maungapohatu, and the awa Te Karae.
description.mi:
Pateoro (Te Karae) marae, is located on Te Karae Road, Kohukohu, in the northern reaches of Hokianga Harbour. 
 
The wharenui is Pōwhiri and the wharekai is Ngā Reo o Ngā Whaea. Pateoro marae affiliates to Te Ihutai hapū within the iwi of Te Rarawa.

description.en:
Waihou marae, in full Waihou-nui-a-rua and also known as Waimirirangi, is located in Waihou, about 4 km south of Panguru on West Coast Road in the northern Hokianga. It's iwi is Te Rarawa, and the hapū associated with the marae include Ngati Te Reinga, Ngāti Moroki, Parewhero, Te Uri o Te Aho and Te Wae Koi. 
The whare tūpuna is called Waimirirangi and the wharekai is Pare Puna o te Ora. Waihou marae connects ancestrally to the waka Mamari, Ngatokimatawhaorua and Tinana, the maunga Te Reinga and the moana Te Hokianga-nui-a-Kupe.
description.mi:
Kei te Huarahi West Coast i Waihou te marae o Waihou-nui-a-rua (Waimirirangi), i Te Tai Tokerau. Nō Ngāti Moroki, Ngāti Te Reinga, Parewhero, Te Uri o Taioho me Te Wai Koi hapū o Te Rarawa.

Ko Te Reinga te maunga, ko Hokianga te moana, ko te Puna o Te Ora te wharenui.

description.en:
Motuti marae is located in the town of Kohukohu on Motuti Road. The hapū of the marae are Ngāti Te  Maara, Te Kaitutae, Ngāī Tamatea, Te Waiariki and Ngāti Muri Kāhara of Te Rarawa.
The wharehui is Tamatea and the whare kai is named Kohinemataroa. Motuti Marae is located east of the Far North papakainga of Panguru off the Hokianga Harbour.
description.mi:
Kei te Huarahi Motutī ki te tāone o Kohukohu, te marae o Motutī. Nō Ngāti Te Maara, Te Kai Tūtae, Ngāti Tamatea me te Waiariki, hapū o Te Rarawa tēnei marae.

Ko Tamatea te wharenui, ko Kohimataroa te wharekai. Kei te marangai o te papakāinga o Panguru i te Tai Tokerau, i te Hokianga te marae o Motutī.

description.en:
Matihetihe marae can be found in the northern Hokianga in the coastal settlement of Mitimiti, just west of Panguru. The wharenui is Tu Moana, and the historic whare karakia is Hato Hemi. The primary hapū is Te Tao Maui of Te Rarawa. It is also connected to several old hapū including Pororewarewa, Ngāti Kaha, Ngāti Hinerangi and Whānaumaii with strong links to Ngāti Ruanui/Te Aupōuri.
It is said that Mitimiti is a spiritual resting place, where those that have passed on drink from the waters of Moetangi before continuing on with their journey to Te Rerenga Wairua (Te Reinga / Cape Reinga).
description.mi: Ko te marae o Mitimiti nō Te Rarawa, kei Hokianga ki te raki kei haka-te-uru o te kāinga Māori o Panguru. Ko Tūmoana te wharenui, ko Hato Hemi te whare karakia tawhito.

description.en:
Waiparera marae is located on Rangi Point Road, about 13 km from Panguru in the northern Hokianga. It's primary hapū are Patutoka, Te Tawhiu, Tahāwai, Te Hokokeha, Te Whānau Pani and Horohuhaare of Te Rarawa. 
The wharenui is Nukutawhiti, the wharekai is Ruamamao and the whare karakia is Ripeka Tapu. This marae connects with the maunga Tauwhare and Pukerangatira, and the awa Hokianga.
description.mi:
Kei te Huarahi Rangi Point i Te Tai Tokerau te marae o Waipārera.
Nō Patutoka, Te Tāwhiu, Tahaawai me Horohūhāre o Te Rarawa iwi tēnei marae.
Ko Nukutawhiti te wharenui, ko Te Rua Mamao te wharekai, ko Rīpeka Tapu te whare karakia.
Ko Tauwhare te maunga, ko Pukerangatira te awa raro mai i te whanga o Hokianga.

description.en:
Te Kotahitanga (Whangapē) marae is located near the Whangapē Harbour and is best accessed via Herekino. 
The wharenui is Te Kotahitanga. Whangapē takes its name from the harbour, also connecting to the maunga named Rangiputa and to the nearby Te Awaroa River.
description.mi:
Te Kotahitanga (Whangapē) marae is located near the Whangapē Harbour and is best accessed via Herekino. 
The wharenui is Te Kotahitanga. Whangapē takes its name from the harbour, also connecting to the maunga named Rangiputa and to the nearby Te Awaroa River.

description.en:
Taiao marae is located at the papakainga of Taiao Makora in the Far North. It belongs to the iwi of Te Rarawa and was established under the ancestral leadership of Te Huhu and Paraihe Papa. 
The primary hapū for the marae is Te Uri a Tai, but it also has links with older hapū such as Kaingamata and Ngati Te Ao. The wharenui is Mātaatua and the wharekai is called Taimania. The marae connects ancestrally to the maunga Makora Taiao and Whakakoro, and the awa Rotokakahi.
description.mi:
Kei te papakāinga o Taiao Mākora i Te Tai Tokerau te marae o Taiao. Nō te iwi o Te Rarawa tēnei marae, i hakatūria i raro i te mana o Te Hūhu rao ko Paraihe Papa.

Nō Te Uri o Tai, Kaingamatā me Ngāti Te Ao hapū. Ko Mataatua te wharenui.

description.en:
Roma marae is located close to Te Oneroa a Tohe (Ninety Mile Beach), Ahipara, in the Far North. It is is widely regarded as one of the oldest marae of Te Rarawa, and is at the spiritual heart of the iwi. It's primary hapū are Ngāti Waiora, Ngāti Pākahi, Te Patukirikiri and Parewhero.
The wharenui is called Te Ohaki and the wharekai is named Maru a Roto (‘storehouse of plenty’). Also located on Roma marae is He Puna, a very large pounamu dedicated to the late spiritual leader Ephraim Te Paa. Roma marae connects to the maunga Whangatauatia and to the moana, Karirikura.
description.mi:
Kei Te Oneroa-ā-Tohe (Ninety Mile Beach), Ahipara, i Te Tai Tokerau te marae o Roma. E meatia ana koia tēnei ko te marae tino tawhito o te manawa wairua o Te Rarawa.

Ko Te Ōhāki te wharenui, ko Maru a Roto (pātaka kī) te wharekai. Kei runga i te marae ko tētahi pounamu ko He Puna te ingoa, i tohia ki te tohunga a Eparaima Te Pā. Ko Whangatauitia te maunga, ko Karirikura te awa.

description.en:
Te Kauhanga marae is in Peria, on the northern side of the Maungataniwha forest. The marae belongs to the hapū Te Paatu within the iwi of Ngāti Kahu, tracing their descent from the waka Māmaru. 
The wharenui is named Te Poho o Ngāti Kahu. Te Kauhanga marae is connected to the maunga Maungataniwha, to the Oruru River and to Tokerau Bay.
description.mi:
Kei raro mai i te ngahere o Maungataniwha, ki Pēria te marae o Te Kauhanga.
Nō Te Pātū hapū o Ngāti Kahu tēnei marae. Ko Māmaru te waka, ko Te Poho o Ngāti Kahu te wharenui, ko Maunga Taniwha te maunga, ko Ōruru te awa, ko Tokerau te moana.

description.en:
Te Paatu marae is located on State Highway 1 near Pamapuria. It is controlled by local hapū Te Paatu and Kaitote, who trace their descent from the chief Tokitahi Tuohu. 
Te Paatu marae connects to the lands of Te Konoti, to the maunga named Kotipu me Pukehapai and to Maungatakauere me Mangataiore Rivers. The wharekarakia is called Hato Tipene.
description.mi:
Kei te ara matua 1 tata atu ki Pāmapuria te marae o Te Pātu. Nō Te Pātu me Kaitote hapū o Ngāti Kahu, ko ngā uri ēnei o te rangatira, Tokitahi Tūohu, tēnei marae.

He pānga tō te marae o Te Pātu ki ngā whenua o Te Konoti. Ko maunga Kōtipu me maunga Pukehāpai ngā maunga, ko Mangatakakauere me Mangataiore ngā awa. Ko Hato Tīpene te whare karakia.

description.en:
Te Rarawa marae is situated on Awaroa Road in Kaitaia. It is associated with the hapū Ngāti Te Ao, Tahāwai and Te Uri o Hina of Te Rarawa. 
The wharenui is also called Te Rarawa and the wharekai is Mahi Tahi. The marae ancestrally connects to the maunga Taumatamahoe and the wai Tangonge.
description.mi: Kei te Huarahi Awaroa i Kaitaia te marae o Te Rarawa. Nō Ngāti Te Ao, Te Uri o Hina me Tahaawai hapū o Te Rarawa iwi tēnei marae. Ko Te Rarawa te wharenui, ā, ko Mahi Tahi te wharekai.

description.en:
Waimanoni marae is located between Awanui and Waipapakauri on State Highway 1, near Rangaunu Harbour. It is one of the major marae of Ngāi Takoto iwi, which descends from the ancestor Tuwhakatere and the waka Kurahaupō. 
Its wharenui is Wikitoria. Waimanoni marae links to the nearby maunga Rangianiwaniwa and to the moana Rangaunu.
description.mi:
Kei te ara matua 1, kei waenganui o Awanui me Waipapakauri, tata atu ki te whanga o Rangaunu te marae o Waimanoni.

Koia tēnei ko tētahi o ngā marae o Ngāi Takoto iwi, i heke mai ngā uri i te tupuna Tūwhakatere me te waka o Kurahaupō.

Ko Wikitōria te wharenui. Ko Te Rangiāniwaniwa te maunga, ko Rangaunu te ngutu awa.

description.en:
Ōturū marae falls within Ngati Kahu tribal region and its principal hapu is Ngāi Tohianga.
The wharenui is called Te Mataara, the whare kai is Huihuinga and the whare karakia is called St Marks.
Ōturū mare connects with Maungataniwha, the awa Oinu, the moana Rangaunu and the waka Mamaru.

Wainui marae is located in Ahipara in the Far North. It belongs to the hapu Ngāti Moetonga and Te Rokeka of the iwi Te Rarawa. The marae also has ties to Te Aupōuri and Ngāi Takoto
The wharenui is called Ngāti Moetonga and the urupa is named Ngatotoiti.

Haiti-tai-marangai (Whatuwhiwhi) marae is located on the south coast of the Karikari peninsula at Whatuwhiwhi. Its hapu are Te Whānau Moana and Te Rorohuri of Ngati Kahu and Te Parata is a key ancestor. 
The wharenui is also called Haiti-tai-marangai. Whatuwhiwhi marae connects to the maunga Pūwheke and to the moana of Karikari.
description.mi:
Kei te ākau ki te tonga o te kūrae o Karikari, ki Whatuwhiwhi te marae o Whatuwhiwhi. Nō Te Whānau Moana me Rorohuri hapū o Ngāti Kahu tēnei marae, ā, ko Parata te tupuna.

Ko Haiti-tai-marangai te wharenui, ko Te Pū-o-te-wheke te maunga, ko Karikari te moana.

description.en:
Parapara marae is in the Doubtless Bay area off State Highway 10 past Taipa. The wharenui, Te Manawa o Ngāti Tara, is named after the principal hapū – Ngāti Tara.
Parapara belongs to Ngāti Kahu and affiliates to the waka Mamaru. The marae links to the maunga Maungataniwha, the awa Te Moho, and the moana Tokarau.
description.mi:
Kei Doubtless Bay, koni tata atu i Taipa tua atu i te ara matua 10 te marae o Parapara. Ko Te Manawa o Ngāti Tara te wharenui, i hua ki te hapū matua o Ngāti Tara.

Nō Ngāti Kahu te marae o Parapara. Ko Māmaru te waka, ko Maungataniwha te maunga, ko Te Moho te awa, ko Tokarau te moana.

locale.mi: Te Hiku o te Ika Marae

description.en:
Kareponia marae is located east of Awanui on State Highway 10. It belongs to the Patu Kōraha hapū of Ngāti Kahu.
Its wharenui is named Patukōraha.
description.mi: Kei te marangai o Awanui i te ara matua 10 e tū ana te marae o Kareponia. Nō Te Patu Kōraha, hapū o Ngāti Kahu. Ko Patu Kōraha te wharenui.

description.en:
Waimanoni marae is located between Awanui and Waipapakauri on State Highway 1, near Rangaunu Harbour. It is one of the major marae of Ngāi Takoto iwi, which descends from the ancestor Tuwhakatere and the waka Kurahaupō. 
Its wharenui is Wikitoria. Waimanoni marae links to the nearby maunga Rangianiwaniwa and to the moana Rangaunu.
description.mi:
Kei te ara matua 1, kei waenganui o Awanui me Waipapakauri, tata atu ki te whanga o Rangaunu te marae o Waimanoni.

Koia tēnei ko tētahi o ngā marae o Ngāi Takoto iwi, i heke mai ngā uri i te tupuna Tūwhakatere me te waka o Kurahaupō.

Ko Wikitōria te wharenui. Ko Te Rangiāniwaniwa te maunga, ko Rangaunu te ngutu awa.

wikipedia.en: The Three Kings Islands, called Manawatāwhi by Māori, are a group of 13 uninhabited islands about 55 kilometres (34 mi) northwest of Cape Reinga, New Zealand, where the South Pacific Ocean and Tasman Sea converge. They measure about 4.86 km² in area. The islands are situated on a submarine plateau, the Three Kings Bank, and are separated from the New Zealand mainland by an 8 km wide, 200 to 300 m deep submarine trough. Therefore, despite relative proximity to the mainland, the islands are listed with the New Zealand Outlying Islands. The islands are an immediate part of New Zealand, but not part of any region or district, but instead Area Outside Territorial Authority, like all the other outlying islands except the Solander Islands.

description.en:
Hurunuiorangi marae is located in Gladstone, approximately 20 km south of Masterton.
The wharenui is called Hurunui-o-Rangi. The marae connects ancestrally to the waka Takitimu (with affiliations also to Kurahaupō), and Maungarake and the awa Ruamahanga and Taueru.
description.mi:
Kei Parakawhara te marae o Hurunui-o-Rangi, āhua 20 kiromita ki te tonga o Whakaoriori.
Ko Hurunui-o-Rangi te wharenui. Ko ōna herenga kōrero ko Takitimu te waka (he hononga anō ki Kurahaupō), ko Maungarake te maunga, ko Raumahanga me Taueru ngā awa.

locale.en: Tama Nui o te Ao Kātoa Hall

description.en:
Te Āwhina marae is located just outside of Motueka in the Tasman region. The marae belongs to Ngāti Tama, Ngāti Rārua and Te Ātiawa and lies in the shadow of two maunga, Pukeone and Tuao Wharepapa.
The whare tūpuna is named Turangāpeke, the wharekai is Te Āwhina (1958) and the whare karakia is named Te Ahurewa (1897). Te Āwhina connects ancestrally to the waka Tainui and the awa Motueka. The kawa for the marae is Tae Nga Kawa.
description.mi:
Kei waho atu o Motueka te marae o Te Āwhina i te rohe o Whakatū. Nō ngā iwi o Ngāti Tama, o Ngāti Rārua, o Te Ātiawa hoki te marae nei, ā, e tū ana kei raro i te maru o ōna maunga e rua, ko Pukeone me Tuao Wharepapa.
Ko Turangāpeke te ingoa o te whare tipuna, ko te wharekai ko Te Āwhina (1958), ā, ko Te Ahurewa te ingoa o te whare karakia (1897). Ko Tainui te waka, ā, ko Motueka te awa o te kāinga nei. Ko te kawa o te marae ko Tae Ngā Kawa.

description.en:
Whakatū marae is located in Taitapu Bay, Nelson. The marae connects to the iwi Ngāti Tama, Ngāti Rārua, Te Ātiawa, Ngāti Koata, Ngāti Toa Rangatira and Ngāti Kuia. Whakatū is the southernmost marae associated with the Kingitanga movement.
The whare tipuna is named Kākāti and was opened on 1 April 1995. Whakatū connects ancestrally to the waka Tokomaru, the maunga Maungatapu and Tuao Wharepapa, and the awa Maitahi. The kawa of Whakatū is Tu Atu Tu Mai.
description.mi:
Kei te koko o Taitapu te marae o Whakatū, ā, ko Whakatū te ikoa o te taone anō hoki. Nō kā iwi o Ngāti Tama, o Ngāti Rārua, o Ngāti Koata, o Ngāti Toa Rangatira, o Ngāti Kuia hoki te marae nei. Ko Whakatū te marae whakatetonga o te Kīngitanga.
Ko Kākāti te whare tipuna i whakatūwheratia ai i te 1 o Paenga-whāwhā i te tau 1995. Ko Tainui te waka tīpuna, ko Maungatapu, ko Tuao Wharepapa ngā maunga, ā, ko Maitahi te awa. Ko te kawa o te marae nei ko ‘tū atu tū mai’.

description.en:
Te Hora marae is located on Te Hora Pa Rd, on the outskirts of Canvastown, and 10 km east of Havelock. The marae belongs to the iwi Ngāti Kuia. 
The whare tipuna is also named Te Hora. The marae connects ancestrally to the waka Te Hoiere, the maunga Tutumapou the awa Wakamarina, Kaituna and Awanui, and the moana Te Hoiere. The first Ngāti Kuia hui held at Te Hora marae was on 18 February 1990. In 2013 construction began on a new wharekai.
description.mi:
Kei te rori o Te Hora Pā te marae o Te Hora, kei waho atu i te taone o Canvastown, ā, 10 kiromita ki te taha whakateraki o Havelock. Nō Ngāti Kuia te marae nei.
Ko Te Hora hoki te ingoa o te whare tupuna. Ko Te Hoiere te waka, ko Tutumapou te maunga, ko ōna awa ko Wakamarina, ko Kaituna, ko Awanui hoki, ā, ko Te Hoiere te moana. Ko te hui tuatahi o Ngāti Kuia ki te tū i te marae nei, i te 18 o Hui-tanguru i te tau 1990. Nō te tau 2013 i timata ngā mahi hanga wharekai hou.

wikipedia.en: Pelorus Sound / Te Hoiere is the largest of the sounds which make up the Marlborough Sounds at the north of the South Island, New Zealand. The Marlborough Sounds is a system of drowned river valleys, which were formed after the last ice age around 10,000 years ago. Pelorus Sound has a main channel which winds south from Cook Strait for about 55 kilometres (34 mi), between steeply sloped wooded hills, until it reached its head close to Havelock town. Pelorus has several major arms, notably Tennyson Inlet, Tawhitinui Reach, Kenepuru Sound and the Crail/Clova/Beatrix Bay complex. Its shoreline runs for 380 kilometres (240 mi).
The Rangitoto Islands are a group of islands near the Marlborough Sounds along the northern coast of the South Island of New Zealand.
The Chetwode Islands are a group of islands near the Marlborough Sounds along the northern coast of the South Island of New Zealand.

Rangitoto ki te Tonga / D'Urville Island is an island in the Marlborough Sounds along the northern coast of the South Island of New Zealand. It was named after the French explorer Jules Dumont d'Urville. With an area of approximately 58 square miles (150 km2), it is the eighth-largest island of New Zealand, and has around 52 permanent residents. The local authority is the Marlborough District Council.

description.en:
Waikawa marae is located in Waikawa Bay, about 7 km northeast of Picton. The marae is a meeting place for Te Atiawa people from the top of the South Island. The whare tupuna is Arapaoa, which means 'downward thrust' and the wharekai is named Whakakotahi, meaning 'to become one'.
The marae connects ancestrally to the waka Tokomaru, the maunga Piripiri and the awa Waitohi.
description.mi:
Kei te whanga o Waikawa te marae o Waikawa, e 7 kiromita te tawhiti atu i Waitohi (Picton). He wāhi huinga te marae nei mō ngā tini o Te Atiawa e noho ana i Te Tauihu o te Waka o Māui. Ko Arapaoa te whare tupuna, ā, ko te tikanga o te ingoa nei kia ‘paoa whakararotia’. Ko Whakakotahi te ingoa o te wharekai, ā, ko tōna tikanga te whakakotahitanga o ngā tāngata.
Ko ngā tātai whakapapa o te marae nei e hono ana ki te waka o Tokomaru. Ko Piripiri te maunga, ā, ko Waitohi te awa.

wikipedia.en: Te Whanganui / Port Underwood is a sheltered harbour which forms the north-east extension of Cloudy Bay at the northeast of New Zealand's South Island, on the east coast of the Marlborough Sounds. With only a relatively narrow entrance to the south-south-east it is sheltered from almost all winds. Originally considered part of Cloudy Bay the port was named after Joseph Underwood of the shipping firm Kabel and Underwood in the early 19th century.
Queen Charlotte Sound / Tōtaranui is the easternmost of the main sounds of the Marlborough Sounds, in New Zealand's South Island.
wikipedia.mi: Ko Totaranui he nohanga o te takiwā o Te Tai-o-Aorere. E ai ki Toitū Te Whenua, he nohanga he wāhi e nohoia ana e te tangata, engari kāore anō kia tae te taupori ki te nui e taea ai te kī he tāone tonu taua wāhi rā.

wikipedia.en: Tory Channel / Kura Te Au is one of the drowned valleys that form the Marlborough Sounds in New Zealand. Inter-island ferries normally use it as the principal channel between Cook Strait and the Marlborough Sounds.

Arapaoa Island, formerly known as Arapawa Island, is a small island located in the Marlborough Sounds, at the north east tip of the South Island of New Zealand.
The island has a land area of 75 km2. Queen Charlotte Sound defines its western side, while to the south lies Tory Channel, which is on the sea route from Wellington in the North Island to Picton. Cook Strait's narrowest point is between Arapaoa Island's Perano Head and Cape Terawhiti in the North Island.
wikipedia.mi: Ko Arapaoa he nohanga o Te Tai-tokerau. E ai ki Toitū Te Whenua, he nohanga he wāhi nohoia e te tangata, engari kāore anō kia tae te nui o te taupori ki te nui e taea ai te kī he tāone tonu tēnei. Ko Te Tai-tokerau tētahi o ngā takiwā o Aotearoa; koia tonu te rohe o Ngā Puhi me ērā atu iwi rongonui o reira.

description.en:
Ōmaka marae is shared by many iwi; principal among these is Rangitane o Wairau and the hapū of Huataki. 
The whare runanga is called Te Aroha O Te Waipounamu and was opened in 1985. Ōmaka marae connects ancestrally to the maunga Tapuae-o-Uenuku, the Wairau River and the Kurahaupo waka.
description.mi:
He maha ngā iwi o te marae nei, hēoi ko Rangitāne o Wairau me te hapū o Huataki ngā mea nui.
Ko te ingoa o te whare rūnanga ko Te Aroha o Te Waipounamu, ā, i whakatūwheratia ai i te tau 1985. Ko tōna karangatanga maunga ko Tapuae-o-Uenuku. Ko Wairau te awa, ā, ko Kurahaupo te waka.

description.en:
Mangamaunu marae is north of Kaikōura township on the coast south of Mangamaunu itself. The primary hapu for this marae are Ngāti Kuri and Te Rūnanga o Kaikōura of Ngāi Tahu. 
The marae was gifted by the elders of Kaikōura for a church reserve in 1890, and the St. Francis Church was subsequently opened there. The wharenui, Hohepa, was opened in 1915; it was named after a Māori acolyte (Hohepa) who brought Catholicism to the Kaikōura Māori. The Mangamaunu area is extremely significant to Ngāti Kuri. It was once known as Kaiwhare, or 'food bowl', because of its bountiful supply of kai from both the land and the sea.
description.mi:
Kai te taha whakararo o te taone o Kaikōura, kai te takutai o Mangamaunu te marae o Mangamaunu. Ko Ngāti Kurī o Ngāi Tahu te hapū matua o tēnei marae.
Ko te wāhi i tū ai te marae i tēnei wā, he whenua tuku i kā kaumātua o Kaikōura ki te hāhi hei whare karakia i te tau 1890, ā, nō muri mai i whakatūria te whare karakia o St. Francis. Nō te tau 1915 te whare tupuna o Hohepa i whakatūwheratia. He mea tapa te whare nei i tētahi o kā kaihāhi Māori, ko Hohepa, ā nāna te hāhi Katorika i haria mai ki Kaikōura.
He wāhi tino whakahirahira a Mangamaunu ki a Ngāti Kurī. I kā wā o mua ko Kaiwhare te ikoa o te wāhi nei nā tōna rokonui mō te nui o te kai o te moana me te kai o te whenua ki tēnei pito.

description.en:
Tuahiwi marae is located between Rangiora and Kaiapoi, north of Christchurch. Tuahiwi is home to Ngāi Tūāhuriri, linking to the iwi of Ngāi Tahu. The new wharenui is named Maahunui II, and was opened on 1 December 2012. It has the simple gable form of a traditional whare but is otherwise unadorned. 
This whare stands on almost the exact site of the ancestral whare tupuna Tū-te-kawa, which stood here until it was burnt down in 1872. Maahunui takes its name from the canoe of the shared Ngāi Tahu ancestor, Māui-tikitiki-a-Te-Raka. Tribal landmarks of Ngāi Tūāhuriri include Maungatere (Mt Grey), Ngā Tiritiri o Te Moana (the Southern Alps) and Ngā Kohatu Whakarekareka o Tamatea-pokai-whenua (the Port Hills).
description.mi:
Kai waekanui i Rangiora me Kaiapoi e tū ana te marae o Tuahiwi, ki te taha whakararo o Ōtautahi. Ko Tuahiwi te kāika o te hapū o Ngāi Tūāhuriri o Ngāi Tahu. Ko te ikoa o te whare hou, ko Maahunui II, ā, i whakatūwheratia i te 1 o Waru i te tau 2012. Ko te āhua o te mahau me kā amo o te whare e pērā ana ki kā āhuataka o kā whare tūpuna e mōhiotia whānuitia, hēoti ano ehara tēnei i te whare whakairo.
E tū ana te whare nei i te wāhi tonu i tū ai te whare tupuna o Tū-te-Kawa i mua i tōna tahunataka i te tau 1872. I ahu mai te ikoa o Maahunui i te waka tupuna o Māui-tikitiki-a-Te-Raka. Ko ētahi o kā tūtohu whenua o Ngāi Tūāhuriri ko te mauka o Maungatere, ko Kā Tiritiri te Moana (Southern Alps) me Kā Kōhatu Whakarakaraka o Tamatea Pōkai Whenua, arā ko kā Port Hills.

wikipedia.en: Port Levy is a long, sheltered bay and settlement on Banks Peninsula in Canterbury, New Zealand. The current population is under 100, but in the mid-19th century it was the largest Māori settlement in Canterbury with a population of about 400 people. It is named after Solomon Levey, an Australian merchant and ship owner who sent a number of trading vessels to the Banks Peninsula area during the 1820s.

description.en:
Ōnuku marae is located 5 km beyond Akaroa township. It is home to the hapū of Ngāi Tarewa and Ngāti Irakēhu of Ngāi Tahu. The whare tūpuna is named Karaweko and was opened on 5 February 1997. The wharekai was built in 1990 and bears the name Amiria Puhirere. Ōnuku connects ancestrally to the waka Takitimu, the moana Akaroa and the maunga Ōteauheke.
The foundation stone for Te Whare Karakia o Ōnuku was laid in 1876, and the church officially opened in 1878 as the first non-denominational church in New Zealand. Ōnuku is a place of historical significance as the first of the three locations in the South Island where Te Tiriti o Waitangi was signed.
description.mi:
E tū ana te marae o Ōnuku i waho atu i te tāone o Akaroa, ā, e rima kiromita te tawhiti atu. Ko kā hapū o te marae nei ko Ngāi Tarewa me Ngāti Irakēhu o Ngāi Tahu. Ko Karaweko te whare tipuna, ā, i whakatūwheratia i te 5 o Kahuru i te tau 1997. Nō te tau 1990 te wharekai i whakatūria, ā, ko Amiria Puhirere tōna ikoa. Ko Takitimu te waka tīpuna, ā, ko Ōteauheke te mauka.
I whakatakotohia te kōhatu tuatahi mō te tūāpapa o Te Whare Karakia o Ōnuku i te tau 1876, ā, i whakatūwheratia i te tau 1878. Ko te whare karakia nei te whare karakia hāhi kore tuatahi i Aotearoa. He wāhi tino whakahirahira a Ōnuku i kā kōrero o nehe, ā, ko tērā hoki te wāhi tuatahi o kā wāhi e toru i Te Waipounamu i hainatia te Tiriti o Waitangi.

description.en:
Ngāti Moki marae is located south of Christchurch on the shores of Lake Ellesmere (Waihora). It belongs to Te Taumutu Rūnanga of Ngāi Tahu. 
The whare tūpuna is also named Ngāti Moki and was opened on 7 May 1891. The wharekai is named Riki Te Mairaki Ellison after a noted kaumatua. The marae connects ancestrally to the waka Takitimu, the moana Te Kete Ika a Rakaihautū, the awa Ōrakaia and the maunga Aoraki and Ngā Tiritiri o Te Moana.
description.mi:
Kai te pito whakaruka o Ōtautahi ki te tahatai o te roto o Waihora te marae o Ngāti Moki e tū ana. Nō Te Taumutu Rūnanga o Ngāi Tahu te marae nei.
Ko Ngāti Moki hoki te ikoa o te wharenui, ā, i whakatūwheratia i te 7 o Mātahi o te Tau i te tau 1891. Ko Riki Te Mairaki Ellison te ikoa o te wharekai, ā, he mea i tapa i tētahi o kā kaumātua rokonui o te rohe. Ko Takitimu te waka, ko Te Kete Ika a Rākaihautu te moana, ko Ōrakaia te awa, ā, ko Aoraki me Kā Tiritiri o te Moana kā mauka.

wikipedia.en: Lake Ellesmere / Te Waihora is a broad, shallow lagoon in the Canterbury region of the South Island of New Zealand. It is directly to the west of Banks Peninsula, separated from the Pacific Ocean by the long, narrow, sandy Kaitorete Spit, or more correctly Kaitorete Barrier. It lies partially in extreme southeastern Selwyn District and partially in the southwestern extension of the former Banks Peninsula District, which now is a ward in the city of Christchurch. The lake holds high historical and cultural significance to the indigenous Māori population and the traditional Māori name Te Waihora, means spreading waters. It has officially had a dual English/Māori name since at least 1938.

description.en:
Arowhenua marae is located in Temuka, South Canterbury. It is situated near a historic Ngāi Tahu settlement in South Canterbury, Te Waiateruati, and the Arowhenua bush. 
The whare tūpuna is named Te Hapa o Niu Tireni. Arowhenua connects ancestrally to the waka Takitimu  and Araiteuru, the maunga Tarahoua and the awa Waitaki and Opihi.
description.mi:
Arowhenua marae can be found in Temuka, South Canterbury. The primary hapu for this marae is KTe Rūnanga o Arowhenua of Ngāi Tahu. 

	 

	Huirapa ancestrally connects to the waka Takitimu and Araiteuru, the maunga Orapuke and Aoraki and the awa Waitaki and Opihi.

description.en:
Waihao marae is located between Oamaru and Timaru, in the township of Morven. The primary hapu is Te Runanga o Waihao of Waitaha, Kāti Mamoe and Ngāi Tahu. Waihao connects ancestrally to the waka Uruao, Araiteuru and Takitimu, and the awa Waihao.
The name Waihao refers to an important food resource obtained from the river that has its beginnings in the upland country behind the hills of Te Tari Te Kaumira. The hao eel, the life stage of the short-fin eel is a delicacy to families who gather mahinga kai from the Wainono Lagoon and the Waihao River (the kete of local Māori).
description.mi:
Waihao marae can be found between Oamaru and Timaru, on the east coast of the South Island. The primary hapu for this marae is Te Runanga o Waihao of Waitaha, Kati Mamoe and Ngai Tahu. Waihao ancestrally connects to the waka Uruao, Araiteuru and Takitimu and the awa Waihao.

	 

	The name Waihao refers to an important food resource obtained from the river that has its beginnings in the upland country behind the hills, Te Tari Te Kaumira.  The hao eel, the lifestage of the short-fin eel was, and still is, a delicacy to families who gather mahinga kai from the Wainono Lagoon and the Waihao River (the kete of local maori).

description.en:
Moeraki marae is located in the coastal settlement of the same name, notable as the home of the Moeraki Boulders.
The wharenui is named Uenuku. Moeraki connects ancestrally to the moana Te Tai o Arai-te-uru, the awa Kakaunui, the roto Waimātaitai and the maunga Te Kohurau.
Moeraki marae belongs to the iwi te Rapuwai, Waitaha, Kāti Mamoe and Kāi Tahu.
description.mi:
Moeraki marae is located in the coastal settlement of the same name, notable as the home of the Moeraki Boulders.
The wharenui is named Uenuku. Moeraki connects ancestrally to the moana Te Tai o Arai-te-uru, the awa Kakaunui, the roto Waimātaitai and the maunga Te Kohurau.
Moeraki marae belongs to the iwi te Rapuwai, Waitaha, Kāti Mamoe and Kāi Tahu.

wikipedia.en: Moeraki is a small fishing village on the east coast of the South Island of New Zealand. It was once the location of a whaling station. In the 1870s, local interests believed it could become the main port for the north Otago area and a railway line, the Moeraki Branch, was built to the settlement and opened in 1877. However, the port could not compete with Oamaru and the lack of traffic as well as stability problems caused by difficult terrain led to the closure of the railway in 1879 after only two years of operation.
Waikouaiti is a small town in East Otago, New Zealand, within the city limits of Dunedin. The town is close to the coast and the mouth of the Waikouaiti River.

description.en:
Ōtākou marae can be found 26 km from Dunedin on the Otago Peninsula. The primary hapu is Te Ruahikihiki with links to Kāti Hawea, Kāti Moki II and Taoka.
The wharenui Tamatea replaced the old meeting house Te Mahi Tamariki, and was built in the period 1940–45, along with the Otakou Maori Memorial Methodist Church, which is also on the site.
Ōtākou marae ancestrally connects to the waka Uruao and the maunga Te Atua o Taiehu and Pukekura (more commonly known as Taiaroa Heads).
description.mi:
Ōtākou marae can be found 26 km from Dunedin on the Otago Peninsula. The primary hapu is Te Ruahikihiki with links to Kati Hawea, Kāti Moki II and Taoka. 
The wharenui Tamatea replaced the old meeting house Te Mahi Tamariki, and was built in the period 1940-1945, along with the Otakou Maori Memorial Methodist Church, which is also on the site.
Ōtākou marae ancestrally connects to the waka Uruao and the maunga Te Atua o Taiehu and Pukekura (more commonly known as Taiaroa Heads).

description.en:
Puketeraki marae is located in Karitane, just north of Dunedin. The marae's primary hapū is Kāti Huirapa ki Puketeraki of Ngāi Tahu. 
The wharenui is named Huirapa. It was carved in 2007 by James York, Ross Hemera and Jenny Rendell. The wharekai is Maririhau. Huirapa connects ancestrally to the waka Takitimu and Araiteuru.

wikipedia.en: Lake Hāwea is located in the Otago Region of New Zealand, at an altitude of 348 metres. It covers an area of some 141 km² and is, at its deepest, 392 metres deep.

Lake Wanaka is located in the Otago region of New Zealand, at an altitude of 278 meters. Covering an area of 192 km2 (74 sq mi), it is New Zealand's fourth largest lake, estimated to be more than 300 m (980 ft) deep. Its Māori name is a corruption of Oanaka.

Lake Manapōuri is located in the South Island of New Zealand. The lake is situated within the Fiordland National Park and the wider region of Te Wahipounamu South West New Zealand World Heritage Area.

locale.mi: Te Hono Ki Ngāi Tāhu Marae

mi.ascii: Te Hono Ki Ngai Tahu Marae
mi.double: Te Hono Ki Ngaai Taahu Marae

description.en:
Murihiku marae is located about ten minutes drive from the centre of Invercargill. It is the local marae for the iwi of Kāi Tahu, Kāti Mamoe and Waitaha, and its primary hapu are Waihōpai Rūnaka and Kāti Huirapa. 
The wharekai, Hine o te Iwi, was the first building on the site when it opened in June 1983. The wharenui, Te Rakitauneke, opened in February 1990. Murihiku connects ancestrally to the waka Uruao and Takitimu, the maunga Takitimu and the moana Te Ara a Kiwa.
description.mi:
Murihiku Marae can be found in Invercargill, on 10 acres of land about 10 minutes from the city centre. It is the local Marae for the Iwi of Kai Tahu, Kati Mamoe and Waitaha. Its primary hapu are Waihōpai Rūnaka and Kati Huirapa. 

	 

	The Wharekai, Hine o te Iwi, was the first builing on the site and opened in June 1983. The Wharenui is named Te Rakitauneke and was opened in February 1990. Murihiku ancestrally connects to the waka Uruao and Takitimu, the maunga Takitimu and the moana Te Ara a Kiwa.

description.en:
Te Rau Aroha Marae, located in Bluff, is New Zealand's southernmost marae. It belongs to the hapu Awarua Rūnanga.
Originally the marae was established in the late 1800s as a hostel for local Māori who lived on islands off the Southland coast. The modern marae was developed in 1985. The wharenui, Tahu-pōtiki, which takes its name from the ancestor (tupuna) of Ngāi Tahu, was opened in February 2003.
Te Rau Aroha connects ancestrally to the waka Takitimu and Uruao, and the maunga Aoraki.
 
Link to Twitter
description.mi:
Te Rau Aroha Marae is the world’s southern-most marae and can be found in Bluff. The marae was originally established in the late 1800s as a hostel for local Māori who lived on islands off the Southland coast.

	 

	The modern marae was developed in 1985, however the tupuna whare, Tahu-pōtiki, which takes its name from the ancestor (tupuna) of the local iwi, Ngāi Tahu, was opened in February 2003.

	 

	Te Rau Aroha connects to the waka Uruao, the maunga Aoraki and the hapu Awarua Rūnanga.

wikipedia.en: Resolution Island or Tau Moana (Māori) is the largest island in the Fiordland region of southwest New Zealand, covering a total of 208 km2 (80 sq mi). It is the country's seventh largest island, and the second largest uninhabited island. Resolution Island is separated from the mainland of the South Island by Dusky Sound and Breaksea Sound. The island is part of the Fiordland National Park.

Chalky Island or Te Kākahu-o-Tamatea is an island in the southwest of New Zealand, and is part of Fiordland National Park. It lies at the entrance to Chalky Inlet/Taiari, next to Preservation Inlet, at the southwestern tip of the South Island, 10 kilometres (6 mi) northwest of Puysegur Point, 15 kilometres (9 mi) southeast of West Cape, and 140 kilometres (87 mi) west of Invercargill.
Pitt Island is the second largest island in the Chatham Archipelago, New Zealand. It is called Rangiauria in Māori and Rangiaotea in Moriori.

The Chatham Islands are a New Zealand archipelago in the Pacific Ocean about 800 kilometres (500 mi) east of the South Island of New Zealand. The archipelago consists of about ten islands within an approximate 60-kilometre (37 mi) radius, the largest of which are Chatham Island and Pitt Island. Some of these islands, formerly cleared for farming, are now preserved as nature reserves to conserve some of the unique flora and fauna.
As of 2013 the islands had a resident population of 600. The local economy depends largely on conservation, tourism, farming, and fishing.
wikipedia.mi: Ko Wharekauri he rōpū moutere, he takiwā motuhake o Aotearoa. Ko ngā Moriori te iwi taketake o reira. E rua ngā moutere nunui: ko 'Wharekauri', ko 'Rangiauria'. Ko 'Rekohu' te ingoa Moriori mō Wharekauri, ko 'Chatham' te ingoa Pākehā; ko 'Pitt' te ingoa o Rangiauria i te reo Pākehā. He wāhi taima anō tō Wharekauri, e 45 meneti i mua o te tuawhenua o Aotearoa.
